@paulgp I'm not saying it's a good idea, I'm just a little surprised that so many econs who know person taxed != person who pays tax are going nuts with "we're going to tax phd students into starvation.

@filomezza With fixed tuition, dept has $X to use for funding. If stipends increase to cover extra taxes (so depts continue to attract quality students) then fewer students get admitted.
But the ability to zero out tuition cld create a large disparity b/w pub. and private, cld be big prob
@paulgp Only as far as stipends are increased to cover the extra tax liability.

@tyleransom I ended up putting my old notes in a Gist and finally cleaning it up a bit. It's roughly but should hopefully be worth something.
https://t.co/vDAbG5Rpdi

@tyleransom One last tip that was something that tripped me up at first: "p" is the past/put command in normal mode. But it won't automatically pull from the system clipboard, you have to use: "*p. Google 'vim registers' to learn more.
@tyleransom If you're interested, DM me your email and I'll send you the list of commands I used when I started.
@tyleransom 5. Do not use your mouse in Vim. At all. The more you lean on it the slower you'll learn, and the whole point of vim is to stop moving your hands between kb and mouse.

@tyleransom 4. When you want to know how to do a thing (search and replace) look it up and add it to the appropriate list. When you feel like you've got a thing learned, replace it with a "to learn" item.

@tyleransom 3. Have two lists: commands I'm learning and commands to learn. Then learn commands incrementally. Start with basic editing (i to insert, a to spend, capital those to do that at begin/end of line) and motion (hjkl to move around).
@tyleransom 2. Use a plug-in manager (allows plug-ins to be managed directly through vimrc. I use VimPlug. (You can then add my Stata syntax file to your vimrc.)
@tyleransom 1. Make some basic quality of life changes to your vimrc file (like remapping <Esc> to jk. See the end of my _vimrc on my GitHub, "dotfiles".
@BenjaminEPark The actor had died and they didn't want to CGI/dub in old voice I think.

@RyanReedHill @JeffDenning `return list` and `ereturn list` are your friends. Especially since Stata documentation doesn't always list everything that commands return.
@RyanReedHill Only because as long as everyone else still uses Stata I still have to use it to some degree....
@RyanReedHill @JeffDenning But `duplicates report` does return `r(unique_value)` which is what we're after. Not sure if its overhead is less than `qui tab`.

@paulgp But `codebook` output can't be used programmatically unless you save the output to a log and then parse it somehow.
You can do `qui tab` and then unique values is saved to `r(r)`, but then you also pay the cost of counting the unique values.
The need for a user-made function "tell me the number of unique values of variable X" seems like a pretty serious indictment of Stata. Add it to the list... https://t.co/vPZztVoIVd

@polumechanos Yup. Less so in U.S. (post clean air act anyway) but there's a lot of variation in exposure by income and race b/c dirty areas are cheaper and once you clean them up they often gentrify. And we still have levels that are definitely not good.

@polumechanos Unless you have asthma or a heart condition, long term exposure is a much bigger concern. But it's a huge concern, with latest research linking particulate matter (PM) pollution to Alzheimer's and dementia.
